remixed_from.title: universal bltouch mount for E3D v6

description.text:
I really liked TNS' mount, but did not have a 3d touch mount. Also, the carriage has a dedicated sensor mount. This means if it breaks or you change mounts, you have to reprint the entire carriage.

This changes that by moving the 3d touch 30mm directly in front of the nozzle. The offset is just that too. I took Rhuuk's mount and combined it with the front mount for TNS to make what you see. Also, included is 2 spacers that can be used to lower your sensor as needed.

TNS' carraige:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577

Rhuuk's universal mount:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1747443

Update: 5/28/17
Added mount to position the touch sensor to the right of the nozzle. Also added the spacers as separate files.

print_settings.Notes:: See below for some helpful printing and assembly instructions

description.text:
Wilma, from the Flintstones cartoon show by Hanna-Barbera.

The Flintstones cartoon takes place in a romanticized Stone Age setting, depicting the lives of the Flintstone family and their best friends and neighbors the Rubbles.

Wilma was modeled in proportion to my Fred and Dino models.
Fred: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1361894
Dino: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1473207

No supports are required. If you have the proper filament colors, no painting is needed.

The model is 280mm tall.

Enjoy, and I hope you have a "Yaba Daba Do" time printing this!

Note to my followers: I completed Wilma last year after posting Fred but did not feel that she was good enough to post at that time. I've learned quite a bit since then so I went back and cleaned her up but did not redo the whole model.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

See below for some helpful printing and assembly instructions

Colors (there are no multiple printed pieces)

White:
dress_top
dress_bottom
teeth
..
Skin or Beige:
face
legs
arm_right_top
arm_right_bottom
arm_left_top
arm_left_bottom
..
Orange:
hair_top
hair-bottom
..
Black:
eyes
eyebrows
..
Grey:
bone
..
Red:
mouth
..
Light Brown:
base
..
Natural or White:
beads (contains 10 individual beads for the necklace)
..
Any color (hidden pieces)
pins (contains 6 individual pins, five used)

Printing and assembly tips

1-Be sure to clean any first layer squish if you have any problem joining parts. The parts should fit nicely when printed cleanly.
..
2-Some of the parts are tall with smallish bases, so you may want to consider using brims for those pieces.
..
Assembly tips:
1-The head snaps cleanly into the hair_bottom piece with some force (no glue required) and should be inserted before gluing the hair_top to the hair_bottom. Another reminder to be sure the first layer squish in the head is fully cleaned off.
..
2-Insert the teeth into the mouth and then glue them together into the head.
..
3-The head has dents for the eyebrows as a guide, simply glue the eyebrows over the dents. The wider part of the eyebrows should be placed towards the center.
..
4-The necklace consists of 10 individual beads with holes in them (you can use fewer beads for a tighter necklace). I used a piece of thread through the holes to connect the beads and tied them tightly together. I then placed the completed necklace over the neck before gluing the head down.
..
5-Due to Wilma's small feet, she would be prone to tipping over, so I've added a base for stability.

Wilma assembly

comments.text: Hey, Steve! I printed Wilma and Fred together (well, in one go anyway) and I am just now putting Wilma together. I take it from your description that Wilma was one of your first models - well, before the rest of the Flintstones. I've noticed that the later models fit together better than the earlier ones - a little more clearance on the pins and fittings. Did you have any trouble getting Wilma together? It may be my printer or my filament, but I didn't have these issues with the same roll of filament on the other models. Wilma's feet, especially. The legs seem too big to fit into the recess in her skirt. I'm going to try my hand at vapor smoothing - I accidentally ordered ABS when I ordered flesh instead of my usual PLA - so maybe that will shrink the size just a smidge?
comments.author: rebeltaz

comments.text: Actually, Fred was my first model, and I tried doing Wilma next but then left her for a year or so on my shelf.  I went back to clean her up as much as possible, so the fit should be good.  The typical issue is if there is a brim it needs to be thoroughly cleaned.  I leave more tolerance for brims these days but other than that the parts should still fit nicely.

author: bornity_

description.text: A spoon with tinkerbell on the handle

So I started with the Tinkerbell silhouette, and used blender to add relief (extruded various parts like the hair, the dress, one leg, inverse extrusion on pupils, whites of the eye, and wings to add depth), and simply overlaid it on a spoon model. the model was kicked to netfabb to make it manifold. The combined model was stretched along one axis to add thickness. This render is full sized (about 8 inches or so), but if it's scaled to z<100mm, Shapeways can print it in metal (steel for just over $30US, silver for just under $100).

comments.text: Well, timing is everything. :-) Valentines day came at the same time as the tax return, so I pulled the trigger and ordered this from Shapeways in their "raw silver" (scaled to ~3inches tall) for the wife. Background: my wife loves tinkerbell. Loves. Seperately, there's a cultural meme she subscribes to about spoons. To paraphrase, "Imagine you start the day with five spoons. Everything you do has a cost--this costs one spoon, this costs another spoon that costs 2 spoons, etc.. You have to manage to get through your entire day before you run out of spoons." So, I made this so I could "give her one more spoon to get through her day." Apparently, they used to make official spoons with this character, but all the ones I could find on ebay were from the 70's and looked pretty rough. Mine may not be much better, but I'll post pictures once it ships. (Also, wife broke me, made me tell her what she was getting, and she was very, very happy.)
comments.author: HaHaRich

comments.text: I don't love it yet. There's a few things where I was learning translation vs extrusion in blender, vertices vs faces vs lines. There's a lot of triangles that are just weird. (around the wings, across the face, etc.) Other things I think will make happy accidents. I actually like the line across the waist, just maybe not so jagged.
comments.author: HaHaRich

print_settings.Notes:: Start with black filament, then when it's done with the top surface at 3mm, switch to white filament.  If your slicer has "pause at layer", you can use this; but I just use my machine's front panel pause button instead.  Just wait for the first layer where it does the outer contours of the white part and pause it then. (At 50% scale this is at 1.5mm rather than 3mm of course)

description.text:
I was inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:446442 but created this version from scratch.

It's designed to be printed in two colors with a manual filament change in the middle. It also has a provision for mounting on a nail.

The openscad source is included, mostly because if you have a multi-extruder setup you'll probably need it if you want to prepare a version that automatically prints in two colors.

12%

Notes:

Infill and resolution don't matter a great deal. I actually printed it at 50% scale.

Start with black filament, then when it's done with the top surface at 3mm, switch to white filament. If your slicer has "pause at layer", you can use this; but I just use my machine's front panel pause button instead. Just wait for the first layer where it does the outer contours of the white part and pause it then. (At 50% scale this is at 1.5mm rather than 3mm of course)

title: Geoff's GT2 Timing Belt pulley Mk2 - fully 3D printed

description.text:
Upgrade to my earlier "Geoff's GT2 Timing Belt pulley", this version does not use a grub screw which marks the 5/6/7mm rod, making it much easier to slide the pulley OFF the rod for maintenance.

I've also changed the teeth shape to more closely match a GT2 belt, as you can see in the (partial) red pulley & GT2 belt pic

The only assembly needed is to push a 3mm screw&nut into each hole - the length varies with Diameter, approx 18-22mm. You may need to drill out the center, depends on your 3D printer calibration setup.

Included are 16T, 18T, 20 and 22T pulleys, each size with 5/6//7/8mm centers (except where the walls are too thin) - PM me if you need other sizes

title: Pyramid Stacker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Pyramid Stacker is angled to the same dimensions of a real Pyramid. It's a series of easy prints that creates a multi-layered storage solution able to accommodate all sorts of small things up to quite large things if you have a build plate big enough to print the larger / lower layers (L4/5). build plate sizes required for the various layers are provided below. Just print up to the layer that your machine can accommodate.

This is a versatile storage solution with a unique look. Great for everything ranging from jewellery through to electronic parts, cables, Lego and other small toys/models, tools, parts and much more... as you would expect with a storage solution of this shape store the smallest things near the top and larger things lower down.

As the layers snap together (if well printed on a precise accurate machine) there is a small tab on one of the four faces of each layer to help with opening / separating the layers to store items away and / or get to the items already stored inside. The critical thing required to get a great result is clean prints with a nice flat base. Good build plate adhesion for larger / square prints is important.

A range of configurations (options) is provided. Choose from a single open space within the layer to having he layer divided onto 2 or 4 equal 'chambers'. Each layer is 30mm in height. For example, to make a 3 layer Pyramid Stacker, print the top (L1), make the next layer down with a divider into 2 chambers (L2-2) then your bottom layer with 4 chambers (L3-4). To explain further, the .stl files are referenced in this way...

L1 = Top

Layer 2: Approx. 96mm square

L2-1 = Open chamber one layer below the top
L2-2 =Chamber divided into two equal areas

Layer 3: Approx. 143mm square

L3-1 = Open chamber two layers below the top
L3-2 = Chamber divided into two equal areas
L3-4 = Chamber divided into four equal areas

Layer 4: Approx. 190mm square

L4-1 = Open chamber three layers below the top
L4-2 = Chamber divided into two equal areas
L4-4 = Chamber divided into four equal areas

Layer 5: Approx. 236mm square

L5-1 = Open chamber at the lowest possible layer
L5-2 = Chamber divided into two equal areas
L5-4 = Chamber divided into four equal areas

The Pyramid Stacker parts are easy prints... just print up to the layer required. On an accurate / well set up machine the layers should snap together securely (so it can be inverted and won't fall apart) with a small amount of effort...

To get a great result you need a precise slicing app and well set up accurate machine. this will affect the fit of one layer into another. however, if your prints won't join the joining edges/surfaces can easily be cleaned up with a craft knife / sandpaper / a file until they do. If your joints are loose... no problem... just don't invert it or the layers will separate.

People the world over like the classic 'Pyramid' shape so this design uses that to create a modular storage solution. You can print just the top (L1) and one layer down (L2) for a mini storage facility... or go all out and print the lot if your build plate allows it.

A practical storage system for your own use but also great as a gift. Print all layers in just one colour or vary the layer colouring to help locate the stored contents you want at the time.

Please refer to the print settings provided as well as the images for additional information.... and post images of your prints in use for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

10% infill / 2 Shells / PLA

Notes:

Nothing too special... however your machine needs to print larger objects with a flat base well so there is no warping / curvature of the base edges. This will ensure a good clean snap fit.

Print the top (L1) and your choice of L2 first to ensure they fit together well (as per the images provided).

Just stack your Pyramid Stacker... nothing else required!

The Pyramid Stacker should be ready to use straight off your build plate. However, it is too tight for layers to snap together you a quick/small file should quickly clean it up so it joins the layers securely but also leaves them easy to separate/remove.

If for some reason your layer joints are slightly loose this is not an issue either... just sit the layers on top of each other as expected and the overlapping parts will align the layers and keep them in place.

Note: Good build plate adhesion is required so your layers have a nice flat base surface. This ensures a good match between the layers when slotted together.

The two mounting screw holes are sized to work with the original hardware from the Hubsan x4 Quadcopter, however one of the screws will press into punkkills' frame behind the mount, I just made sure my flight board, board mount, and frame were all pressed firmly together before putting in that screw. The screw will go through the mount and into the frame.

V1 and V2 have a 1mm thick bottom, V3 has a .6mm bottom with .4mm stand offs.

print_settings.Notes:: This print took 7 Hours and 14 Minutes for me to print at 60mm/s using Cura 2.5 as the Slicer.

title: Final Design for Press Reset Challenge #SKATEFORCE (Single stud wall mount-smoothed out trucks holder)

description.text:
This was tested with all of the weights I have at 46lbs, the thing didn't even budge a little. It was solid as a rock. The print material was done with Zyltech PLA 1.75mm. (Cheap stuff $11.45 per 1kg on eBay) It is not the greatest to work with but it proves that even cheap filament can hold a ton of weight. The print settings were 210C and 65C on the bed at 60mm/s with 25 Percent infill. The time it took to print was just over seven hours. This was secured to the wall with just one-inch long roofing screws as that was all I had to fasten with. If I can find more weight I will try again. Anyway thanks for looking. (Also it was printed with no supports and there is a version without the LOGO too)

Final Design for Press Reset Challenge #SKATEFORCE see link for challenge contest:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pVH-GfD4Sfo&t=1s

author: Supercell

description.text:
Apparently, instead of gold stars and the like, the school are doing something with the kids getting a token for "being good" which they put in a jar. At the end of the week they see how good they have been and if they are missing any.  
I was originally asked for some simple 2D shapes, but they wanted to fill a 1l jar, so I have made a set of regular Platonic solids, each 50ml volume, with the lettering for a.m. and p.m. for each day, they are printed a different colour for each day (hence separate files).  
The days are in order, tetrahedron, cube, octahedron, dodecahedron, and icosahedron. So this should be a bit educational as well.  
Update: Apparently these work really well. In fact, we need Saturday and Sunday, which is a slight issue when there are only 5 Platonic solids. I have added a cone (Saturday) and a Sphere (Sunday).  
I have also tidied up the text and made them print better and re-loaded all of the files.

author: Tman12000

title: Realacc X210 V+ / Pro Canopy, vtx options!

description.text:
A couple of canopy options for a Realacc X210 Pro / X210 V+. After I broke my top plate in a crash with a wooden gazebo during a race, I made this. It features reinforced shoulders and screw points to ensure crashes don't completely destroy it.

It fits with my Runcam eagle mount, which I drilled holes in the frame to mount.

I've used both a TBS Unify style and Eachine TX526 transmitters, so I have created styles for both. Further, there is a model without any VTX or antenna fixins, so you can drill / exacto your own.

Lots of overhang, so support material is suggested. TPA or TPU, the stiffer the better. The Inland stuff from microcenter works great for me.

Designed in Fusion360, source available at http://a360.co/2qcHfxS

comments.text: Hi, how does the carriage behave when printed with PLA? Doesn't it warp with the heat radiating from the bed?
comments.author: gael_pouger

comments.text:
Hi. The bed is located at a certain distance from the carriage, so when the offset is heated to 60-70 ° C, the carriage has no deformations and is heated to 35-40 ° C
Hot air rises, so the stool warms up less than the bed.
I think if you heat the bed above 100 ° C, then the carriage may overheat, but I have not checked it yet.

title: xbox 360 plugin mount for ATX psu case

description.text:
I was building an case for my Gen7 electronics from an old atx psu case that died ages ago, but was wanting to power it from an xbox 360 power supply, but couldnt find anything that I really liked, so I made this.  
The whole thing fits inside of the plastic piece, but is big enough to withstand the constant unplugging and plugging the power brick in. I just drilled all of the holes out and used long 6/32 screws to firmly mount everything really firmly.   
There's tons of info for how to hook up the 360 psu, but I didnt just simply short the sense+5v together, I ran it down into the switch built into the atx case, it makes a very easy way to shut off the 12v stuff, but keeps the 5v standby running so that you can have temperature readings or whatever or work on stuff without worrying about damaging anything.

comments.text: if you have a low enegry psu but it isint enoph to power youre ststem wire it to a psu that worcks with youre system i go it to save money and a less risk of blowing out a fuse

Then it would be able to tell the temps and stuff with the psu turned off, just like the ATX connector on it controls the atmega off of the psu standby line.

"A nucleosome is the basic unit of DNA packaging in eukaryotes, consisting of a segment of DNA wound in sequence around eight histone protein cores. This structure is often compared to thread wrapped around a spool."
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleosome This model is based on Protein Data Bank entry 1KX5:
http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore.do?structureId=1kx5
There are separate STL files for the protein and DNA components. Model created using VMD:
http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/

Successfully made in PLA by a Replicator 2 using MakerWare 2.2.2.89. Standard resolution, 25% infill, 3 shells, raft and supports.  
It may be tricky to fit the DNA model around the protein (Histone complex) model. If the DNA model snaps a little superglue can be used to fix it around the protein model.

title: Wanhao i3 plus/Cocoon Create minimalist enclosure

description.text:
This is an enclosure for Cocoon Create/Wanhao i3 Plus 3d printers. Mine is constructed from 6mm acrylic, but you could also use MDF or plywood. This enclosure has been designed to allow easy access to the power switch, while still enabling the entire build volume, and to take as little space as is possible.

These files have a couple of fixes compared to my original enclosure. The front box now sits inside the small tower bolts, and the rear box comes down hard on the top of the tower so there's clearance for larger filament spools.

The DXF file contains outlines for all panels, as well as 600x400 sheet borders. For cutting the acrylic it's recommended that you use a laser cutter (see your local fab-lab). If building out of ply/mdf, then you could simply print the DXF files and use them as templates. The design currently uses 4 sheets of 600x400 (that's what my fablab has available), but there's a fair bit of free space, so with care you could get away with less.

Update: Apparently the units are wrong in the STL. Scale up 10x (mm to cm) before printing. If I get some free time I'll upload updated STLs.

Update 2: This enclosure works with the reverse Z braces I developed. However, the design uploaded is 5mm lower than the version I made as it is designed to sit on top of the printer tower. To use the Z-braces as well, either cut the panels 5mm longer at the base, or use the riser brackets included with the Z-brace files.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

Lots

Notes:

Update: Apparently the units are wrong in the STL. Scale up 10x (mm to cm) before printing.

The screw holes in this are 2.5mm diameter. If you use heavy gauge screws then it may be worth using heavy wall thickness, lots of infill, or drilling out the screw holes a bit to minimise the chance of breaking the plastic brackets.

I used 8g x 15mm screws and drilled out the holes to 3.3mm.

Bracket names are rather obscure
First character - front or rear enclosure
Second - back or front of that enclosure (as per front of printer)
Third - Top, middle of bottom brackets
Fourth - Left or right (as facing the printer)

Basically, print them all out and it should be obvious where they fit.

I've modified the Wild River 240 to work with 2020 profiles. I've also modified the carriage to be a 50mm horizontal bar spacing instead of the short vertical. At larger print distances the twist on the closely spaced bars was significant, causing issues with the leveling sensor.

Initially I am including only CoreXY parts. Z can be done in many different ways. This carriage is dual extruder, single 40mm fan, and space for a capacitive proximity sensor. I have yet to test this horizontal configuration, but it looks promising. The proximity sensor is in the middle of the carriage to best get an accurate reading.

The extruders are spaced 67.685mm apart.

Update: New carriage_base.stl file added. The original base was not large enough for the sensor to fit.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxB6V_Y3zuE

title: fan duct for Geeetech Prusa i3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was looking for a fan duct for my Geeetech Prusa i3 and found lots of them, but didn't really like any of those, because they weren't designed like I design my things.

I would have liked to edit existing designs, but noone would upload step-files. I want to do that so you can work with the CAD program you like..

The last picture shows why it's not a good idea to use the type of fan - the gap leaks a lot of air! A radial fan would have been better, but I used parts that came with the Geeetech printer - all the screws were included and the fan was dismounted from the heatsink - this will work just fine, because the heatsink never got hot or even warm (room temperature even after hourlong prints).

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I uploaded the GCODE for the braket as well, because I think my print came out really fine. The supports to the braket were easy to remove and it didn't need any tidy-ups (except for the removal of the brakets).

I used CATIA V5 for designing the parts.

This is actually the 2nd try since the first design collided with the spring clamps for the glass plate and the braket just had a hole, so I had to hold the nut while adjusting which was quite awkward.
The braket will hold both M3 hex or square nuts (I used a quare nut).
Screws needed:
two M3 5mm to screw the braket to the extruder holder
one M3 8mm with a washer and a nut to screw the braket and the fan duct together
depending on your fan four screws with nuts (15mm in my case) and the fan already had the hex moulded in the fan casing.

description.text:
A simple last-resort tool to open stuck ground glass stoppers.
Some precautions:

  • try all other tricks in the book first
  • glass can break if too much force is applied
  • wear proper eye protection and leather gloves
  • be prepared for whatever could happen in case the contents get spilled.

Use at your own risk.

I fitted this to the NS14.5 and NS29 standard stoppers I had around. They seem to be rather irregular though, mine had variations of more than 1.5mm. If you run into problems, scale up the print slightly or adjust the parameters id14 / id29 in the scad file.
NS24 tolerances untested!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed with more infill to increase strength. Print with opening facing up.

Does the hexagonal part fit your stoppers?
comments.author: TFMvdBroek

comments.text: My father was a "Glasbläser"/glassblower and made such parts out of glass. When he had problems to open it, he put the whole bottle into warm/hot water to expand the air inside the bottle. That helped in most cases and is much saver than putting any force on the plug. For sure the plug hast to be removed as long as the air is warmed up. If you wait until it's cooling down again you have the opposite effect.
comments.author: TuxMan

comments.text:
I agree, hence "try all other tricks in the book first". In many cases you cannot heat up the whole bottle due to sensitive content. Or it would have no effect because there is no air in the bottle to start with :-) I usually apply a blowtorch or heatgun carefully to the ground glass connection, then gently rap it against a soft piece of wood. If that fails, the printed tool is my last resort (and much better than using pliers or worse). Used to have a simpler one machined from PVC in my old job.
To be fair, if you're careful it should be fine. I never broke a stopper in my entire career.

I removed the lower bar in my helix 45 degreee headso I can do more proxy acro stuff. The problem I had was the camera kept jumping up and moving around, so I made this tiny bracket to hold it in place. I use PETG, but anything would work.
Size: 6 x 6 cm

title: Xiaomi Yi remote wrist strap holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Xiaomi Yi camera has a great small remote for use with a selfie stick, but I don't know why there isn't any way to use this remote with a strap (or I didn't found anyone). So there it is.

It's simply as it seems. Print, put a strap and put on your wrist.

Note for yi_remote_holder_v5.stl. After printing, I had to sand (hard sanding, even with a knife) the big inner part to hold the remote. So I recommendo you to print it scaled a little, or better if you edit the file to make a little more space.
Here is the source: http://a360.co/2qmlngZ

Note for yi_remote_holder_waterproof.stl. This holder has some more space, but it's fit enough to hold the remote in place without problems. This space allow to put the remote into a water baloon, and then the remote is waterproof.
Here is the source: http://a360.co/2qHddz3

I recomend to print the waterproof version even if you are not going to put it in water.

Printer:

Zonestar P802NR2

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

70

description.text:
This is a clip on prop guard for the Eachine E52 pocket 'selfie' drone. [and the RXM JY-018]

This is a really cool and cheap little quadcoptor that can be controlled via a smartphone of dedicated transmitter.

The guards can easily be looped over the props to fit without removing them.

I have included a model of the props themselves, but these will be hard to print on most printers.

I have also included the Designspark CAD model for anyone who wants to do a remix.

Update :- I have added a lighter weight version that should reduce the flight time impact. The original one weight approximately 1 gram each. The new version is probably about 50% less than that, but will not be as robust.

description.text:
These are two adaptor plates to turn a normal Repap with the extruder on the X-carriage into a two hot-end printer. The T shaped part fits where the hotend would.
The large part bolts to the x-carrage and can hold two hot-ends. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/fsba2cAItSM

Print this.
Unbolt your hot-end & extruder.
Connect these two parts with a PTFE tube that has a M5 nut on each end.
bolt the large part to the x-carriage.
bolt the small T shaped part to the extruder where the hot-end was.
bolt the hot-end to the x-carriage. Now you can print a second extruder and T-shaped part to add a second hot-end to your printer.

Hi,
This is a mod of the Auto bed leveling using piezo discs by elenhinan for the kossel mini.

Having a rigid (rigidity is a must!), 0 backlash, all metal (MGN12 rails + MGN12H carriage) printer and good fine tune can make very fine prints. I haven't needed auto bed levelling for a long time. But recently I had to print small figurines with a 0.2 nozzle and 0.1 layer height. Every time I change the nozzle, I had to recalibrate the printer. So, having any other kind of bed levelling (inductive, optical, mechanical switch (etc) on the effector would be useless for this purpose. The piezo bed leveling by elenhinan is excelent in this case. The sensors are in the bed mounts and the measurement is done exactly from the nozzle tip with 0x, 0y, 0z offset.

So, as my printer is a little weird (the heated aluminium bed is larger then normal) I had to make my own mounts.

I made a simple stick with mounts that can deform a little (to bend the piezo disk) but rigid enough to keep the bed in place. This is done in ABS (not PLA !!!)
The bed can be connected in one of 3 holes (for mounting flexibility) with a m3x10mm screw, leaving the other 2 for the piezo actuator screw (also m3x10mm). I am using different screws for the bed and piezo to reduce the piezo disk heating (heat can damage it). You can put a small piece of FR4 (pcb without copper layer), say 5x5 mm, between the disk and the screw as a heat break). Also, I raised the bed from the mount with some washers and a M4 nut(you can use any spacer here al long as it will not deform) so it will not touch the piezo screw.

The Piezo disk (20mm diameter) is stuck to the 20x20 aluminium rail with kapton tape (1 layer as isolation on the rail, and 1 layer over the piezo disk).
The mount sits over it with the actuator screw touching it (tighten this screw until it puts some tension on the sensor)

For the electronics, I used the first schematic (the one with a single LM358M dual op-amp)
uploaded by elenhinan. It works very good for me.You can adjust the sensitivity of the bed sensor with the R8 resistor. I set mine to trigger just by lightly tapping on the bed.
I used simple electrical wire for the sensors (piezo disks). Twisting them gives some em rejection. I will upgrade the wiring to coaxial microphone cable if I need to.
To minimise false triggering, I routed the wires away from the stepper motors.

A note on the piezo disks. Use simple, no integrated electronic amp, no plastic case disks. Buy more then 3 (they are very easily damaged during soldering). Test each one with a multimeter by gently bending it in one direction and note the polarity. I found reversed polarity disks in the same batch. They can be used by connecting the wires in reverse.
Test each disk by itself on the schematic. To work properly, the sensor neds to trigger when the bed is pushed down, not when it springs back up. Slowly push the bed with your finger. If everything works fine, the led will light up when you push on the bed and stay dark when you let go. If it's dark when you push, and it lights up when you let go, connect that piezo in the other way around.
Note that the piezo generates a voltage (negative or positive depending on the direction) when it actually bends, NOT when it stays bent (under load, tension). It is not a button/switch.

For 3 mounts you need:
6 m3 nuts
6 m3x10mm screws
6 tslot/vslot nuts and screws (in my case I use m4)

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

0.2

Post print

Use superglue to glue the m3 nuts in their slots.

Trigering the sensor by tapping it. This is a test with the bed in place. The sensor is not mounted in the case yet. printed piece Piezo disk with kapton tape the pcb module disk without wires

comments.text: Welcome to the small but exclusive club of those who know that inexpensive piezo discs can be used to make a Z sensor better than anything else available. There is a lengthy discussion about various ways of using Piezo disc sensors on http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,635075 To the best of my knowledge all of this was built on the original design by elenhinan
comments.author: leadinglights

comments.text: Hi, Leadinglights. Just read the entire thread (nice!). I will try the TLC274CD schematic in the future. I am currently in the process of designing a raised effector for added Z height. I'll try to include a drilled piezo disk in there (did not know this fragile piezos can be drilled :) ). Having only one sensor make sense as in my current build one of the 3 piezos is noticeably more sensitive and i have to tune that with the actuator screws.
comments.author: leadinglights

comments.text: Nice!
comments.author: elenhinan

comments.text: Thanks !! Your first circuit (LM358) design works great, without false triggering, after some sensitivity adjustment.
comments.author: elenhinan

comments.text: It's probably easier to use the piezo method with a kossel, since the bed doesn't move. When the bed moves, you have to filter out the nudge due to acceleration and vibration from the stepper from the signal. I'm happy it works well for you :)

"The Lords of the Beyond after being banished left behind a large strip of devastated land, with ghost towns, buildings, temples and a whole range of localities. Rumors that in these places existed treasures, weapons and a whole range of fantastic things, began to arrive in the ears of the people of our world.

Individuals in search of fame and fortune have decided to enter these cursed lands in search of these prizes. Organized in small groups, they enter these lands and there they face dangers. This is the premise of Scavengers, a skirmish game in the devastated lands, where you lead a group of adventurers in search of fame and fortune.

Extracted from Alabar Chronicle´s, a Scavenger Guide to Our World"

Introduction

Scavengers is a table top miniature war game for fighting skirmishes with fantasy/steampunk figures. Two players fight a small scale combat with five to ten miniatures on each side (a hero and your henchmen). The game is easy to learn and play, though there is enough depth that it will take time and experience to master.

The game was designed around three core premises.

a) You can download our 3D models or use any miniatures in their collection. Thus, the game is not specifically designed to any particular manufacturer or company. But if you like to help the game dev, please download our models! (They are free and paid...)

b) It is important that the miniatures on the table be the focus of the game. In the end, miniature gaming should be about miniatures (and fun!)

c) A large background - We´ll develop new units, histories and game scenarios. But we need your help, sending suggestions to improve the game!

I hope you like our game and have fun! Ahh, an important thing: this is the basic core rules, our idea is releasing other books to improve the game!

This is a human archer you need to print 3 for a stand. Our gaming site is coming with our core book, game lore and a lot of new things!

This adaptor allows the user to point the remote control to an exact tv. Useful in case you have several tvs nearby

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eKX89b6fTJ8

author: JaG_UK

description.text:
The other day one of our best friends had knee surgery. I created this model so he can point out to all of us what bits he had replaced...  
He's doing very well btw... and was really happy with the print.

Just print straight out... no support should be necessary (the kneecap is a bit less round than it should be to make it easier to print). So the entire thing is a bit of an "artistic interpretation", but close enough for it's purpose.  
I disabled the floor layers in my print so you can see the honeycomb fill pattern from the bottom... shows people what's inside the print.. which they seem to like (and I certainly do).

Raspberry Pi driven chaser lights for K8200 printbed enlightment. Using
OctoPrint events with runable Python script for event handling and starting LED sequences. Standalone runner with buttoncontrolled demo mode and developing sequences. Hardware layouts included Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xRhgaWbLEP4 (How could i add this to the gallery??)

i did a Remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:155262 , but i what more lights, use my M3 screws for mounting the ring and -of course- i what to control every LED for itself. So i rebuild the ring for 12 LEDs and desgin a M3x16mm screws capable mount. Thus far everything works fine, but controlling 12x 5500MCD-LED with 14mA per led may burn the Raspberry Pi GPIOs. To turn LEDs on and off for seconds or minutes with 5v(500mA) from a free USB-Port is no problem - I'm so mighty, i can make light!
On the other hand -let Raspberry Pi GPIO controll LEDs that external powered- could handle the power problem with the Pi GPIOs. I start reading ... AH transistors ... multiplier hfe ... what? ... RTFM ... ah gpio->resistor->transistor->"CONTROL" ... after days of reading
physics, math, calculating, understanding, failing and keyboard biteing the plan stands with bias resistors for transistor controll and
matching LED resistor arrays. I ask a colleague for checking my calculations and he advised Darlinton-Arrays to me. Darlington Arrays combine all the suff i calculated days ago and its build for TTL inputs from Pi's GPIO, great! Thanks Robert! So all i need is calculate the LED bias resistors and combine everything on a small prefboad. Thanks to www.fritzing.org i can provide a full circuit diagram for rebuilding it yourself!

The prefboad buffers 14 GPIO pins(3.3v) to 5v include 12x 150Ohm resistors and 2x 300(2x150)Ohm.
One GPIO (pin 26 3.3v OUT) used without Darlington Array as one LED controll with bias resistor.
Two buttons connected to I2C witch allready has a 1.8kOhm pull-up resistor so i don't need resistors for button controll.
So you get 15 ouputs(3 onBoard) and 2 Inputs. I use the 12(150Ohm) as chaser lights on my remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:155262 ,
the three on board LEDs for OctoPrint Sever and Printer status (Server Startup, Printer Connected etc)
and the 2 Buttons for chaser light controll (play funky light sequences)

Cause the presents of 1.8kOhm Pull-Up resistors i use the SDA/SCL as inputs for Buttons.
Addressed: Pin 3,5 - GPIO-BCM(Rev.2 Board) 2,3, WireingPi Pin 8,9
The Pull-Ups turn the inputs to HIGH, in default state your Buttonpress turn the Input to LOW.
So:
Pressed = 0, Low, False
Normal = 1, High, True
That annoying behavior looks kind of "unlogic" ... so i connect the Buttons (they have two connections for Pressed = connected or Pressed = cut Connection)
other way to get a logic behavoir: Pressed = 1,True Normal = 0,False.
While you connect the Buttons after Booting this works perfect!
BUT after i try to restart the "RainbowScreen" stays and no SD-Card Reading was recognizable (little green LED on Pi). That driving me nuts, everything works fine AFTER booting ... some coffes later i decided to trail and error this out!
All measurements going fine - no shorts, no unwanted soldering ... have to be a logic problem!
It was .. MY Logic problem!
After turnaround the Buttons logic i short circuit the Pi itself through connect ping 3,5 to ground over the Buttons.
Pi Boots if you press both buttons, nice for unwanted access (noobs blocked, too) but very annoying for development. Turnd the buttons back to "normal" behavior:
Pressed = 0, False, Low
Unpressed = 1, True, High
and handle this in Code :]

It's my first Python-Project ever so don't be harsh, i'm open minded and happy about codereviews and feedback :)
All python code can be found here https://github.com/thomaskneisel/LightRider
I'm still a Python noob so its stay a while in "progress" :)

• get rid off that "fleshburningsunlike" living room lamp

    • until i use SÃÂ¶rli - the first 3D-Printer part Ikea ever invented (good job btw) - everytime i watch the
      printer doing his work i get blinded for 4-5 min
    • Now you say: "Stop watching, you dirty peeper!", but i love to watch my little printer working :D

  • learn some "useable" Elektronics

    • controll something "really useful" with a self written program
    • Microcontroller concept
    • Raspberry Pi GPIO as "Microcontroller"
    • Watt is Voltage and Current ;)
    • "Short Circuit" is not a Hipster-Band, its not even a friend!
    • Calculate bias resistor for LEDs
    • Transistors or "why Darlington Arrays are awesome!"
    • Soldering - don't burn yourself! - still try that
    • Build concepts on Breadboard
    • Plan own Prefboards on Computer
    • Build my own "hardware"
    • don't incinerate my Raspberry Pi, printer, house or myself!

  • learn Python

    • Syntax
    • Project Structure
    • OOP
    • CommandLine tool
    • Raspberry Pi GPIO with Python
    • Input handling with running program e.g. ButtonDaemon(BuDae)
    • UnitTesting (@TODO)
    • "read" and understand code from an other person

  • let OctoPrint take controll of hardware

    • On Board Status Lights
    • run chaser light sequences by event
    • create some GUI Command to permit control
    • try "Event Driven Command Line API" (Stateless)
    • How To RPC in Python ?

  • Controll via 2 Hardware Buttons

    • On/Off - keep lights on, overwrite states from other instances!
      • while Sequence playing to break sequence loop (static var ?)
    • Program-Button
      • plays sequences incremental
        • import all from sequence folder
      • loops until On/Off Button - to stop sequence looping
      • Press for next sequence

  • consolidate openScad skills

    • reuse code (screws)
    • How to use for loops to place reapeated holes in circular shape
    • "Remix by rebuild"

  • Unite OpenSource Prints with OpenSource Code based on a OpenSource Platform controll OpenSource 3D-Printer!

    • http://www.thingiverse.com/
    • http://www.github.com/
    • http://www.raspberrypi.org/
    • http://reprap.org/wiki/RepRap/
    • OpenWorld!

  • drink a lot of coffee :D

  • "Use" English as Project language
    • Till we "Start hacking away" in Job

title: Ulticampy central carriage for one E3D v6 hotend and 18 mm bed probe
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After having my Ulticampy printer for a while I realized that I do not want to try dual material printing with two nozzles, because then I have to align the nozzles in x,y and especially z direction accurately to each other. Also auto bed levelling would not work as well then and there is the danger, that the then unused nozzle scraps over the part. (However i want to try two materials in this style: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1680034 ) So I was not happy with the older central carraige with room for two nozzles so I designed a new one and printed it.

The carraige features a space for a 18 mm bed probe and a slot for the nut.
It is designed to fit my E3D v6 clone but of course you can customize it to your needs in FreeCAD.
The design in FreeCAD is not very pretty as I used lots of boolean operations, but it worked for me.
It uses two 40 mm fans, one for the hotend, and one for part cooling (the old radial fan did nothing at all to cool the part, with the new one on full power the bed cannot keep up^^). The 40 mm fans are also much quieter than those 30 mm fans that are shipped with cheap E3D v6 clones.
I also got a bit more space in the Z direction, as the nozzle is a bit higher. The carriage is ab bit smaller than the original one so now I've also got a bit more freedom in the X and Y direction.

If you print it for yourself you should perhaps adjust the clearances for the linear bearings in CAD or dremel away afterwards.

Ulticampy

title: S-360-12 Power Supply Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a cover I made for the Power Source I use on my printers. The Cover has holes for all the connectors I used and the on/off button. To go from the power source to my MKS Base I used Banana Plugs that can be used up to 30A. The switch I used is a regular double pole switch you can find in any electronic or hardware store. To connect the power cable you can use any connector you want that is without the fuse and switch integrated because there is a hole for a double pole switch already.

There is a version that has slots for 1 pair and 2 pair of connectors. Up to you which one you need. I needed 2 pair of connectors to connect my mosfet seperate from my MKS to my Power Source but if you don't have a mosfet you won't need it.

author: rowosoft

title: Moon Phases - Portuguese Spanish Italian French Versions

description.text:
Portuguese, Spanish, French and Italian version of the Moon Phases. The files no labels and incomplete files are exactly the same as the original one, just put it here as well so it is easier to get the all package. This way the student can learn a little bit about the other languages as well (if they want to) while learning English.

Sliced fine with a 0.4 nozzle, so it should be fine printing.

This project hasn't been tested with students yet.
NGSS

Portuguese, Spanish, French and Italian version of the Moon Phases. The files 'no labels' and 'incomplete' files are exactly the same as the original one, just put it here as well so it is easier to get the all package. This way the student can learn a little bit about the other languages as well (if they want to) while learning English. 
This project hasn't been tested with students yet.

Very Easy: Print out the models and let the students copy it first, since its a new language.
Easy: Print out the unlabeled model and have the students label the phases in a language of their preference with a permanent marker
Medium: Print out the unfinished model and have the students color the moon phases and label them in a language of their preference with a permanent marker

Chess board for my http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:230724. The Tiles are 43x43mm. For normal 3D Printers (I'm sure someone could make a dual extrusion version of this, but I don't know how and don't need it). WARNING: I have not jet printed this! I need to make some changes to my printer before i can (new better printbed, 24V heatbed upgrade). Therefore I cannot guarantee that all the parts fit perfecty!

You need min. 200x200mm build plate!
Settings for Printer K8200:
I used these settings for the tiles:
Layer hight: 0.3 (lowres)
25% infill
Top/bottom layer infill: concentric
Fill pattern: concentric
Solid layers: Top: 3 Bottom:1 By using only one solid layer on the bottom I reduced the amount of filament needed drastically. Yes that and the concentric infill makes the tiles slightly unstable, but they are made to fit into the chess board (which gives the needed stability)and also will never need to take much strain. Settings for the Board:
I haven't printed it yet, but I'm going to use:
Layer hight: 0.3 (lowres)
25% infill
Top/bottom layer infill: concentric
Fill pattern: honeycomb
Solid layers: Top: 3 Bottom:3 The board gives the tiles stability, and therefore needs to be stronger.

title: Bearingless Snitch Try 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Getting mildly obsessed with converting spinners to not needing bearings (makes them less of a choking hazard risk around wee ones & special needs kids - the bearing can be popped out and swallowed as evidenced by a recent news story). Here's a conversion of my Golden Snitch fidget spinner to be bearingless. Still haven't upped my game enough with the 3D design to get the wings looking nicer, and with the lack of a bearing the only way to do a full circle for the ball part of the Snitch would be to print separate & glue it on at my skill level. I'd be thrilled if someone made a mod of this that was capable of having the Snitch be a ball, added in some details on the ball and/or wings, etc - if you've got the capabilities please tinker this! Bearingless spinners, as far as I can figure, MUST be printed WITHOUT supports (need the gap internally) so that complicates making this a more fully realized 3D effect. I'd be thrilled to see someone make caps for the one that requires a bearing to continue the curve of the ball and make the wings less flat if no one can think of a way to make this one that way.

The photo of the two tone one was printed with gold filament and then had the wings painted silver with nail polish. I don't recommend trying to paint the area that needs to be able to move, though this one has a slightly wider gap than my other bearingless spinners in case people printing it don't have gold filament & need to be able to paint it. I've been having good results with the nail polishes from Dollar Tree for painting on PLA.

Don't make these to sell unless it's selling as a fundraiser for a non-profit. I'm happy to see them used as a non-profit fundraiser, particularly for Harry Potter Alliance groups.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lO0eTtOjs9S

Printer:

New Matter MOD-t

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

100

Notes:

The one pictured was printed with layer height at .1 and I think shell .8 - if the shell is too thick I've been having gaps on the top layer of thin sections even with 100% fill. Layer height needs to be on the finer side for the ball to look nice and it helps with the inner spin.

This hook was designed for the purpose of hanging a garden trellis net from a cable, but probably has applications elsewhere. It was designed to have a very low poly count and straight lines for fast slicing and printing. While this hook isn't limited to its application in the garden, you can find a little bit more about its application and more of a write-up with some info on a couple other printable garden accessories here: http://www.protoparadigm.com/2012/05/what-to-do-with-a-3d-printer-make-garden-tools/

The scad file is parametric, so you can adjust the overall length, the gap (same on both sides), and the thickness of the hook.
Print and enjoy.  Good luck with your beans, peas, and other and other climbers.

title: D-Bot Core-XY Auto Shutdown Modification (usable for any RAMPS v1.4 board)

description.text: I’m sure most of us do our 3D prints unattended and after the print, it will just leave the 3D printer there eating away at your electricity. There are similar mods around using end stops trigger or a timer, solutions that ain't neat. I did some searching and found the perfect electro mechanical device that can simply turn off your printer with the M81 gcode command and also a soft switch to turn on the printer just like on the desktop computer. The printer is completely shutoff with no stray or standby current. Here's how the auto shutdown looks like at the end of the print: https://youtu.be/3tQqf38rrog

5V 1 Channel Relay Module with OPTO Isolation High And Low Level Trigger
https://www.amazon.com/HiLetgo-Channel-Isolation-Support-Trigger/dp/B00LW15A4W

Push Button Switch 12mm
https://www.amazon.com/Momentary-Mounted-Metal-Pushbutton-Switch/dp/B00O9WDO4E

Inlet Male Power Socket with Fuse Switch 10A 250V 3 Pin IEC320 C14
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00511QVVK

Spare wires

Refer to the wiring diagram for build.

The essential part of this mod is the 5V Relay Module which is able to trigger on low signal. You can build one using an optocoupler but that's just too much work :P I got mine directly from Shenzhen, China at like USD $0.5 for a piece.

The wiring diagram (not drawn to standard) basically shows the connections, color coded to represent the labels and the corresponding connections.

The housing for the circuits and socket fits exactly between the joints on the rails if you are using the same instructions from spauda01’s wonderful D-Bot Core-XY printer. It will only fit if you have the exact space or more, not less.

The housing comes with a sliding lock lid so you don’t waste extra screws securing it.

The soft switch push button is 12mm diameter on the threaded part. If you are not able to get the exact one, you can just try to edit my STL files and fit a button to your liking, as long as it supports your AC power rating. The LED light connection for the button is optional, I left mine out.

1. Before turning on, the hard switch has to be at the ON position.

  2. Turn on your printer by pushing the soft switch push button, hold for 1 or 2 seconds for the relay to trigger. Your printer should be turned on and running stable.

  3. Using Repetier-Host, in Slic3r, go to ‘Configuration > Printer Settings > Custom G-code’. On the right, in the box ‘End G-code’, add in ‘M81’ on the last line. This command will send a HIGH signal from your RAMPS to the relay module that will cut off power to your printer.

  4. At this point, any new print object you “slice” will turn off after the print. To disable just remove the M81 command line.

  5. After the printer auto shutdown, turn on the printer again simply by pressing the soft switch push button.

  6. To turn off the printer at any time, you can only do it with the hard switch if it's a standalone unit. However it is possible to create a gcode file with just a M81 command in it, select that file for print and it will shutoff the printer.

comments.text: I like this design but would change the circuit and put the manual (main) switch on the outside of the circuit for safety. Instead of taking the live directly to the relay, take it to the switch.  Then from the switch to the relay.

M109 S70 doesn't work in case of a cooling down!!!! The "S" set a target temp to reach and wait only if current temp is below!

So the correct G-code line to add before the M81 is M109 R'temp'.

title: chubby mini spinner - M8 hidden nuts

description.text:
This is a mini-spinner (65mm width) that embeds two M8 nuts and a standard 608 bearing.
The nuts add the necessary weight in order for the spinner to spin longer. The body is designed so that the nuts and the bearing are perfectly hidden.

The body is made by two parts (plus caps) perfectly matchable.

instructions (see images too):

1) print all the spinner parts (stl files). It took me about 40 mins to print all the parts together.
2) push the bearing and the M8 nuts in their housings in part01 (largest part)
3) take part02 and push it on part01 until the two parts are perfectly joined. Help yourself with a rubber hammer, if necessary
4) plug the caps
5) spin!

Happy printing!

please, take a look at my other things here: https://www.thingiverse.com/nicuz/designs

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hzr0PqTzLZB

This chassis is designed to be used with this battery pack https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2346235 . This allows this chassis to have a low center of gravity, making it very stable. The gearbox is mounted vertically which leaves a lot of space for electronics and additions. All that is needed is 2 M3 X 10 bolts and 2 nuts.

NB The voltage output by the 6 AA batteries is too high for the motors to handle without using PWM. I use a max duty cycle of 60%.

This is a remix of two ideas:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:327387
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/flashforge-creator-pro-fan-duct-2058

It is a 'press-fit' holder that mounts onto the FlashForge Carriage under the right Extrude Fan.
It takes a 10mm deep 40mm Duct Fan.
We prefer an independently wired outside power supply for the Fan with a switch to turn the Fan on/off FYI.

You can remix this to fit the left side too.
BUT a Dual Fan assembly may be unfeasible ... but not to worry, most people use Only the Left or Right side nozzle for PLA printing.

Printed with these settings using Simplify3D:
PLA
0.15 layer
10 top layers, 10 bottom layers, 2 outline shells
12% infill
35c bed temp
200c nozzle temp
60mm speed

title: Pool fountain with valve for switching between jet and fountain

description.text:
I wanted a fountain, so I designed one and also a valve to allow me to switch between jet ciruclation and fountain. The assembly attaches to a standard pool jet. Please see the following video to understand how it works, video is best than just writing explanations here: https://youtu.be/eHzg6lwoskg

Here you can see it in action (in fountain mode): https://youtu.be/X9eyqNJj4Go

The bracket you see on top is a loose fit, it just prevents the assembly to put unnecessary pressure to the pool wall screws since the water pushes the thing back. It acts kind of like a spacer thingy. You can go without it if you want, but I prefer it.

For the top spray nozzle, I initially created a much more complicated design, which allowed me to turn a ring (printed in place) and select one of 3 different spray patterns. Unfortunately, with clearance between parts of 0.4mm, water was leaking. With clearance 0.2mm---I was not able to separate the two parts after the print. Hence I decided to stick with a single static spraying pattern.

What you need: a piece of 3/4" PVC pipe (determine length between pool jet and water level, you want the spray fountain to be above the water level). In the assembly video I've already glued the valve to the pipe, and intend to do so with the nozzle. Alternatively, you can just use some screw, it will hold it alright. It's a tight fit anyway, as you can see in the "in action" video, it didn't shoot the sprayer out at all (still, I will glue it).

I'm happy with how it turned out, because even when you change the valve for standard water circulation, a little water gets into the pipe and into the nozzle, keeping it cool (I printed this in PLA and don't want it to melt in the sun). The only thing that is not cooled is the above the water part of the bracket.

One interesting after-effect is when I remove the plug completely. Then we have water coming out of the jet, as well as from the fountain, but not as strong. Gives a nice ambiance sound :)

Any questions, please ask in the comments section, I'll be happy to answer since this creation of mine is my favorite I've done so far. My kids totally love it too! PLEASE POST A PICTURE IF YOU MAKE ONE, I'D LOVE TO SEE HOW IT LOOKS IN YOUR POOL!

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25% to 100%, see notes

Notes:

All printed with .2 resolution.

Valve body: print with 4 walls and 25% infill. It has an integrated support inside (see the picture showing Cura layers view, I've put comments in the screenshot).

Ball joint: 4 walls, 25% infill. Ideally, I'd go as much infill as possible, I just didn't want to wait when I printed it. 25% seems to work fine. After printing, cut out the single layer on the bottom opening (put there for better adhesion to the bed)

Jet and plug bolt: 4 walls, 100% infill

Valve plug: 4 walls, 25% infill.

Sprayer: 4 walls, 25% infill. Print the way it's positioned in real life. I've put a single .3mm layer on the bottom (essentially blocking the hole) in order to help with bed adhesion. Cut out after the print.

comments.text: Does it cool down the water temperature of the pool?  There are a few products sold online that create a fountain for cooling down pools.  Just wondering if you noticed the same results.

This is a simple 3D model of a chainsaw I made

I think it is very dangerous if you do not protect 220V
So i made a simple box for the MKS PWC Controller Board
I am not an electrician and I do not know if it will get hot. But so you can not touch accidentally to the dangerous parts.

Things i use...

MKS PWC Controller Board

MKS Gen V1.4 (Good alternative)
MKS TFT32
4x M3x20

Marlin Firmware
MKS-TFT Firmware

MKS Gen V1.4 with 5PCS TMC2100 (Do not buy this shit. I only got the A4988 and not as described the TMC 2100)

Please be careful!
High voltage using on your own risk!!!

Let me know if anybody needs the configs.

My printer is not finished and I could not test the auto shutdown function after the print yet. But the M81 command works fine with the TFT and the Button.
I think there will be no problems with the gcode command in the slicer software.

Maybe I'll make a small video soon ;o)

Cheers & have fun

I have my Ormerod 1 extruder cooling fan screwed directly onto the fins of the heat sink. This duct simply pushes on to the side of the heat sink and directs some of the air down close to the part/extruder nozzle to provide a bit of cooling - necessary when printing PLA. It is easily clipped into place and removed. It is nothing special, but might solve someone's problem!
14/6/2017 I have updated the part to a better design with more air going to the end of the nozzle.

Use this small quadrant to measure the altitude of celestial objects. The small star-disc is used as a plumb bob at the end of a short length of string. Run the string between the hole in the upper left of the device to the small hole passing through the bob. Arrange the length so that the bob just reaches the angle scale.
It goes without saying that you should never use this quadrant to directly look at the Sun.
But use can hold the device properly so that the Sun's light travels down the sight tube to cast a shadow, therefor making Sun angle measurements possible.

For more, visit my astronomy class website at carpecaelum.com

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jYzMgFtwhlP
I have a lab exercise that I have yet to re-locate that I will post on my website.  The astrolabe can be used to introduce the basic idea of how celestial objects move across the sky.
Using a Quadrant Lab will be online summer of 2017 ( I hope)
approximately 10 cm of string
